hints: Known for pyramids and pharaohs.
Civilization along the Nile River.
Ruled by Tutankhamun.
Led by emperors like Julius Caesar.
Known for its powerful military and road network.
Capital was Rome.
An armed combatant who entertained audiences.
Fought in arenas like the Colosseum.
Often a slave or criminal.
The period between the fall of Rome and the Renaissance.
Also known as the Middle Ages.
Characterized by feudalism and knights.
A period of renewed interest in art and learning.
Began in Italy in the 14th century.
Known for artists like Leonardo da Vinci.
The policy of acquiring and exploiting territories.
European nations expanded their empires.
Example includes the British Raj in India.
Began in 1914.
Involved the Central Powers and the Allies.
Often referred to as the Great War.
Began in 1939.
Involved the Axis Powers and the Allies.
Ended with the defeat of Germany and Japan.
A period of political and military tension after WWII.
Involved the United States and the Soviet Union.
Ended with the fall of the Berlin Wall.
A social system where land was exchanged for military service.
Dominant in medieval Europe.
Involved lords, vassals, and serfs.
A series of religious wars sanctioned by the Catholic Church.
Fought to reclaim the Holy Land.
Took place in the Middle Ages.
Norse seafarers from Scandinavia.
Known for raiding and trading.
Landed in North America centuries before Columbus.
An Egyptian pharaoh.
His tomb was discovered in 1922.
Known as the Boy King.
A Roman general and statesman.
Played a critical role in the demise of the Roman Republic.
Assassinated on the Ides of March.
A French military and political leader.
Rose to power during the French Revolution.
Conquered a large part of Europe in the 19th century.
Ruled the United Kingdom for 63 years.
Her reign was known as the Victorian Era.
The longest-reigning monarch until Elizabeth II.
The 16th President of the United States.
Led the country during the Civil War.
Issued the Emancipation Proclamation.
A physicist and chemist.
Pioneered research on radioactivity.
The first woman to win a Nobel Prize.
An American civil rights activist.
Delivered the 'I Have a Dream' speech.
Advocated for nonviolent protest.
Founder of the Mongol Empire.
United the nomadic tribes of Northeast Asia.
His empire was the largest contiguous land empire in history.
Birthplace of democracy and philosophy.
Known for city-states like Athens and Sparta.
Home to the Parthenon.
A citadel or fortified part of an ancient Greek city.
The most famous one is in Athens.
It means 'upper city'.
A Roman slave who led a major slave uprising.
His revolt was known as the Third Servile War.
He was a Thracian gladiator.
A Spanish explorer and conqueror.
Explored and colonized parts of the Americas.
Examples include Cortes and Pizarro.
A devastating global epidemic of plague.
Occurred in the mid-14th century.
Caused a massive decline in Europe's population.
A state that controlled much of Southeast Europe, Western Asia, and North Africa.
Lasted from the 14th to the early 20th century.
Its capital was Istanbul.
The forced relocation and incarceration of Japanese Americans.
Occurred during World War II.
Authorized by Executive Order 9066.
A guarded concrete barrier that divided Berlin from 1961 to 1989.
A symbol of the Cold War.
Its fall marked the end of an era.
A social system in medieval Europe.
Land ownership was the basis of power.
The lord and vassal system.
A forcible overthrow of a government or social order.
Examples include the American and French versions.
Often a time of great change.
A period of significant technological advancement.
Began in Great Britain in the 18th century.
Shifted from agrarian to manufacturing economies.
Founder of the People's Republic of China.
A Chinese communist revolutionary.
His policies led to the Great Leap Forward.
The deliberate killing of a large number of people from a particular nation or ethnic group.
Examples include the Holocaust and the Rwandan Genocide.
A struggle for social justice in the United States.
Took place during the 1950s and 1960s.
Led by figures like Martin Luther King Jr.
A charter of rights agreed to by King John of England.
Signed in 1215.
Limited the power of the monarch.
A severe worldwide economic downturn.
Began in 1929 with the stock market crash.
Resulted in widespread unemployment.
The largest empire in pre-Columbian America.
Located in the Andes Mountains of South America.
Known for its stone architecture.
A conflict during the Cold War.
Fought between North and South Vietnam.
Involved the United States.
A major political scandal in the 1970s.
Resulted in the resignation of President Richard Nixon.
Named after an office building complex.
The murder of a prominent person.
Often for political or religious motives.

A system in which individuals are owned as property by others.
A major cause of the American Civil War.
Leader of India's nonviolent independence movement.
Promoted civil disobedience.
Known for his salt march.
A King of England.
Known for his six marriages and his role in the English Reformation.
Separated the Church of England from the Roman Catholic Church.
Queen of England and Ireland from 1558 to 1603.
Known as the Virgin Queen.
Her reign is often called the Elizabethan era.
A French peasant girl who led the French army to victory.
Burned at the stake.
A patron saint of France.
A family of rulers in China.

Forced Germany to pay reparations.

A major event leading to the American Revolution.

A series of fortifications built to protect against invasions.
It is one of the largest construction projects in history.
It is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
An ancient Mesoamerican civilization.
Known for its calendar and hieroglyphic writing.
Built impressive cities and temples.
Mesoamerican empire that ruled from 14th to 16th century.
Its capital was Tenochtitlan.
Conquered by the Spanish.
Also known as the Old Stone Age.
Characterized by the use of stone tools.
Humans were hunter-gatherers during this period.
Also known as the New Stone Age.
The period of the agricultural revolution.
Humans began farming and domesticating animals.
A prehistoric period.
Characterized by the use of copper and its alloy, bronze.
Followed the Stone Age.
A period characterized by the widespread use of iron.
Followed the Bronze Age.
Occurred in different places at different times.
An ancient city in Mesopotamia.
Known for its Hanging Gardens.
Ruled by King Hammurabi.
A Thracian gladiator.
Led a major slave revolt against the Roman Republic.
The uprising was known as the Third Servile War.
A king of the ancient Greek kingdom of Macedon.
Created one of the largest empires in history.
His conquests spread Greek culture.
A Norse explorer.
Credited with being the first European to set foot on continental North America.
Son of Erik the Red.
An Italian explorer and navigator.
Completed four voyages across the Atlantic Ocean.
Credited with discovering the Americas for Europe.
A Portuguese explorer.
His expedition was the first to circumnavigate the Earth.
He died in the Philippines.
The smallest independent state in the world.
Home of the Pope.
An enclave within Rome, Italy.
An Italian diplomat and philosopher.
Wrote 'The Prince'.
His name is associated with cunning and ruthless tactics.
A period of social and political upheaval in France.
Began in 1789.
Led to the end of the monarchy.
The last king of France before the revolution.
Executed by guillotine in 1793.
His wife was Marie Antoinette.
A series of conflicts between France and other European powers.
Led by Napoleon Bonaparte.
Followed the French Revolution.
The final defeat of Napoleon Bonaparte in 1815.
A famous battle in Belgium.
He was exiled after this defeat.
A German philosopher and revolutionary.
Wrote 'The Communist Manifesto'.
Father of Communism.
A political and economic ideology.
Advocates for a classless society with communal ownership.
Opposite of capitalism.
An economic system based on private ownership of the means of production.
Driven by competition and profit.
The dominant economic system in the modern world.
A policy of extending a country's power and influence through diplomacy or military force.
A driving force behind World War One.
Related to colonialism.
A form of fighting where opposing forces occupy fortified trenches.
Characteristic of World War I.
Led to a stalemate on the Western Front.
A period of political and social revolution in the Russian Empire.
Began in 1917.
Led to the creation of the Soviet Union.
The dictator of the Soviet Union from the mid-1920s.
Ruled with an iron fist.
Led the country during World War II.
Leader of the Nazi Party.
Chancellor of Germany from 1933 to 1945.
His actions led to World War II and the Holocaust.
The 32nd President of the United States.
Led the country through the Great Depression and World War II.
The only president to serve more than two terms.
A US naval base in Hawaii.
Attacked by the Japanese in 1941.
The attack led to the US entering World War II.
The Allied invasion of Normandy on June 6, 1944.
Began the liberation of German-occupied France.
The largest seaborne invasion in history.
A Japanese city.
The target of the first atomic bomb in 1945.
The bomb was named 'Little Boy'.
The genocide of European Jews by Nazi Germany.
Systematic mass murder.
Led to the creation of concentration camps.
A series of military tribunals held after World War II.
Prosecuted prominent members of Nazi Germany.
Addressed war crimes and crimes against humanity.
An intergovernmental organization founded in 1945.
Replaced the League of Nations.
Its main goal is to maintain international peace and security.
An American initiative to aid Western Europe after WWII.
Provided financial assistance to rebuild economies.
Named after US Secretary of State George Marshall.
The Soviet Union blocked the Western Allies' access to West Berlin.
Occurred during the Cold War.
Led to the Berlin Airlift.
A war between North Korea and South Korea.
Fought from 1950 to 1953.
The US fought on the side of the South.
A failed US-backed invasion of Cuba in 1961.
Attempted to overthrow Fidel Castro.
A major embarrassment for the Kennedy administration.
A 13-day confrontation in 1962.
Involved the US, Soviet Union, and Cuba.
The closest the Cold War came to a nuclear war.
A competition between the US and the Soviet Union.
To achieve superior spaceflight capability.
Ended with the Apollo 11 moon landing.
A US congressional resolution passed in 1964.
Gave President Lyndon B Johnson authority to use military force in Vietnam.
Escalated US involvement in the Vietnam War.
A famous music festival in 1969.
Symbolized the counterculture of the 1960s.
Held in upstate New York.
Occurred on November 9, 1989.
Symbolized the end of the Cold War.
Led to the reunification of Germany.
A conflict in 1990-1991.
Waged by a US-led coalition against Iraq.
Followed Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
A series of terrorist attacks in the United States.
Occurred in 2001.
Targeted the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.
The period of European history from the 5th to the 15th century.
Also known as the Medieval period.
Characterized by the feudal system.
Norse seafarers from Scandinavia.
Known for raiding and trading.
Landed in North America centuries before Columbus.
A series of religious wars sanctioned by the Latin Church.
The goal was to recover the Holy Land from Muslim rule.
Occurred during the Middle Ages.
Founder of the Mongol Empire.
One of the most feared and successful conquerors in history.
His empire was the largest contiguous land empire.
An ancient network of trade routes.
Connected the East and West.
Caravans transported silk, spices, and other goods.
A German inventor.
Introduced printing to Europe.
His invention was the printing press.
A major movement within Western Christianity.
Started by Martin Luther in 1517.
Challenged the authority of the Catholic Church.

A time of great exploration and artistic flourishing.

A Spanish fleet of 130 ships.

A conflict fought primarily in Central Europe from 1618 to 1648.
Mainly a religious war between Protestants and Catholics.
One of the longest and most destructive wars in European history.

Fought from 1754 to 1763.
Part of the Seven Years' War.

A confrontation in 1770 between British soldiers and a mob.

A document that declared the American colonies' freedom from Britain.

The final major battle of the American Revolutionary War.
Cornwallis surrendered to Washington.

The first ten amendments to the US Constitution.

The acquisition of the Louisiana territory by the United States.

A conflict between the US and Great Britain.

The forced removal of Native American tribes from their homelands.

The largest battle of the American Civil War.

A major cause of global conflicts.

A series of religious wars from 1096 to 1291.
Fought by Christians to regain control of the Holy Land.

A French peasant girl who led the French army.

A conflict that began in 2003 with the invasion of Iraq.

A Chinese dynasty from 618 to 907 AD.
Often referred to as the golden age of Chinese civilization.

Known for its economic and technological innovations.
Invented movable type printing.
A grandson of Genghis Khan.
Founder of the Yuan Dynasty in China.
The first Mongol to rule all of China.

Moved to the Northeast, Midwest, and West.
Occurred from 1916 to 1970.

A nationwide constitutional ban on the production, importation, transportation, and sale of alcoholic beverages.
In the US from 1920 to 1933.

The switching of the first letters of words in a sentence.

A war fought between communist North Vietnam and South Vietnam.
Involved the United States.
Lasted from 1955 to 1975.
A war waged by a US-led coalition against Iraq in 1991.
Followed Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
Also known as Operation Desert Storm.
An empire that controlled most of Europe and the Mediterranean.
Its capital was Rome.
Its fall is often dated to 476 AD.
A civilization known for democracy, philosophy, and epic poetry.
City-states included Athens and Sparta.
The Parthenon is a famous building from this era.
A civilization along the Nile River.
Known for pyramids, hieroglyphs, and pharaohs.
Ruled by Cleopatra and Tutankhamun.
A Mesoamerican civilization.
Known for their calendar, writing system, and pyramids.
Located in present-day southern Mexico and Central America.
A pre-Columbian civilization in the Andes Mountains.
Known for their road system and stone buildings.
Their capital was Cusco.
A Mesoamerican civilization that flourished in central Mexico.
Their capital was Tenochtitlan.
Known for their advanced agriculture and pyramids.
A period of cultural and artistic rebirth in Europe.
Began in Italy in the 14th century.
Known for artists like Leonardo da Vinci and Michelangelo.
A movement to reform the Catholic Church.
Began in the 16th century.
Led by Martin Luther.
A period of European global exploration.
Began in the 15th century.
Led to the discovery of new trade routes and lands.
A global conflict fought between 1756 and 1763.
Involved most of the great powers of the time.
Known as the French and Indian War in North America.
A political and military struggle between Great Britain and the American colonies.
Led to the Declaration of Independence.
Resulted in the formation of the United States.
A war fought in the United States from 1861 to 1865.
Fought between the Union and the Confederacy.
Led to the abolition of slavery.
An executive order issued by Abraham Lincoln in 1863.
Declared slaves in Confederate territory to be free.
A key step toward the abolition of slavery.
The treaty that officially ended World War I.
Signed in 1919.
Forced Germany to accept responsibility for the war.
An intergovernmental organization founded after World War I.
Aimed to promote peace and cooperation.
Precursor to the United Nations.
A severe economic downturn in the 1930s.
Began with the stock market crash of 1929.
Led to high unemployment and poverty.
A series of programs and reforms enacted in the US.
Aimed to combat the Great Depression.
Led by President Franklin D Roosevelt.
A US naval base in Hawaii.
Attacked by the Japanese on December 7, 1941.
The event led to the US entering World War II.
The genocide of six million Jews by the Nazi regime.
A central event of World War II.
Led to the creation of concentration camps.
The Allied invasion of Normandy on June 6, 1944.
Opened a new front against Germany.
The largest seaborne invasion in history.
A competition between the US and the Soviet Union.
To achieve superiority in spaceflight.
Began with Sputnik and ended with the Apollo program.
A physical barrier that divided Berlin from 1961 to 1989.
